subject: linear_algebra
title: Linear Transformations: Definition and Linearity Conditions
contentHtml:
A linear transformation is a fundamental concept in linear algebra that maps one vector space to another while preserving certain properties.

In this card, we'll explore the definition, linearity conditions, examples, and non-examples of linear transformations.

formula.latex: \[ T: V \to W \text{ is a linear transformation } \]
formula.name: Linear Transformation Definition

theorem.statement: \[ T(\mathbf{x}) = c_1 \mathbf{v}_1 + \cdots + c_k \mathbf{v}_k, \text{ where } c_i \in \mathbb{R}, \mathbf{v}_i \in V, \mathbf{x} \in V \]
theorem.proofSketch: The proof involves showing that the transformation satisfies the properties of linearity and preserves scalar multiplication.

intuition: A linear transformation is like a stretch or shrink operation on vectors. It keeps their direction but changes their magnitude.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, linear transformations are used in neural networks to transform input data into a more suitable representation.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Linear Transformations: Definition and Linearity Conditions
contentHtml:
A linear transformation is a fundamental concept in linear algebra that describes how vectors are transformed from one space to another.

In this card, we'll explore the definition, linearity conditions, examples, and non-examples of linear transformations.
intuition: A linear transformation preserves the operations of vector addition and scalar multiplication, making it a fundamental concept in many areas of mathematics and computer science.
realWorldApplications: Linear transformations are used extensively in machine learning to transform data from one space to another, such as feature scaling or dimensionality reduction.
